xls utilities¶

simpleutils.simplexls.basic_read_sheet(filename=None, workbook=None, sheet_name='', preserve_styles=False)[source]¶

reads a sheet from a workbook or file (workbook can either be a workbook or worksheet).

Caution

Rough function!

This is still really rough, so be careful when using.

simpleutils.simplexls.get_worksheet(workbook=None, sheet_name=None)[source]¶
Returns:a tuple of (workbook, worksheet) for given workbook and sheet_name

Parameters:

Parameters:
  • workbook – a workbook object (supports both get_sheet_by_name and add_sheet command), if None, creates one
  • sheet_name – the sheet to be created or returned. if sheet_name is None, uses default name from openpyxl (generally “Sheet#”)
simpleutils.simplexls.make_filename(filename=None, ext='.xlsx', prefix='', **kwargs)[source]¶

excel-specific wrapper for make_filename

simpleutils.simplexls.write_dict(lstofdicts, filename=None, fieldnames=None, col_titles=None, row_styles=None, col_styles=None, style_dict=None, sheet_name=None, workbook=None, col_sort_key=None, ignore_keys=None, default_style=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Takes a given list of dicts and converts it to an excel file, using similar settings to write_dict in csv.

Special Parameters:

Parameters:
  • row_styles – sequence callable by row integer
  • col_styles – sequence callable by column integer: (where ‘A’ –> ‘0’)
  • style_dict – mapping from cell names (‘A1’) or cell pos((0,1)) to a format object
  • workbook – either an openpyxl workbook object or a string denoting the desired workbook title.
  • sheet_name – string - name of sheet in which to store data (if sheet name already exists, it will be overwritten, otherwise one will be created)
  • col_sort_key – key function for sorting column names for eventual output
  • col_titles – list of column titles...if len(col_titles) < list of fieldnames found, remaining fieldnames will be appended to column titles
  • ignore_keys – keys to ignore in dicts (these will not be written to file)
  • append_time – (kwarg only!) - append_time - if True, write_dict() will put the header_row as the first row (or, if one is not given, generate one, so be aware of this)

for each entry, write_dict() will lookup to see if there exists a row_style or a column_style corresponding to that entry returns worksheet created (note can get workbook from worksheet by: worksheet.parent)
